bgc:general.bgc:title: Physico-chemical and microbial soil properties and plant diversity of AEG31, 2011, SCALEMIC-Experiment

bgc:methodology.bgc:introduction: Scalemic Experiment investigates the spatial and temporal changes in microbial community composition and nitrogen cycling processes at the plot scale (10m x 10m) under different stages of plant growth in a low land use intensity grassland.

bgc:measurements.bgc:theory:
The SCALEMIC experiment used a detailed investigation of spatial and temporal patterns in microbial community structure and function to determine the relationships between microbial communities and their local environment. This was done within a large interdisciplinary cooperation (see list of related datasets).
The SCALEMIC experiment took place in 2011 on the plot AEG31. On a 10 m x 10 m plot 30 subplots (each 2 m x 1.67 m) were established. Each subplot contained six pairs of sample locations, from which one pair of sample locations was randomly sampled at each of six sampling dates over the growing season (April 5th, May 17th, June 27th, August 16th, October 5th, November 21st) (for details see Regan et al. 2014).
bgc:measurements.bgc:type: Functional gene abundances of nitrogen cycling microorganisms Spatial characterization of microbial communities with geostatistics soil nutrients, plant community composition

bgc:equipment.bgc:instruments: For details see Regan et al. 2014, 2015, and 2017 Soil Biology an Biochemistry
bgc:equipment.bgc:procedures:
According to Regan et al. 2014 and Regan et al. 2017 (see these publications for more details):
Sampling: Aboveground biomass and plant species were recorded on a 20 cm x 20 cm area that was centered over each of the sixty individual sampling points. Biomass was harvested by cutting all plants at ground level and sorted into litter, grasses, legumes, forbs, bryophytes and Rhinanthus minor. Plant biomass was determined gravimetricall after drying for 48 h at 80 °C. Plant species were recorded for May, June and October.
Sample preparation: The soil was sieved < 5 mm and roots, stones and animals removed.
Soil analyses: Soil water and dry matter content (SWC, DM) were determined gravimetrically; the soil samples were dried at 105 °C until constant weight was reached (overnight).
Bulk density (BD) was determined on a separate core, which was weighed, measured and dried for three days at 105 °C before weighing it again. Afterwards, root biomass was determined gravimetrically on this core after washing and drying (three days at 60 °C).
Soil texture was determined by laser diffraction analysis (Beckman Coulter LS200 laser diffraction particle size analyzer, Beckman Coulter GmbH, Krefeld, Germany).
Soil pH was determined in 0.01 M CaCl2 (soil to solution ratio w/v 1:2.5).
Bioavailable phosphorus (P) fractions in soil was determined by the second step of the sequential P fractionation by Hedley et al. (1982).
Organic carbon and total nitrogen were analyzed with a MACRO CNS Elemental Analyzer (Elementar-Analysensysteme, GmbH, Hanau, Germany). As total C contained <0.1% carbonate, total C was assumed to be organic C.
Mineral nitrogen in form of ammonium (NH4+) and nitrate (NO3-) was determined by DIN ISO 14256-2 (2006) with an AutoAnalyzer 3 (Bran & Luebbe, Norderstedt, Germany) using the undiluted and unfumigated extracts of the CFE analyses.
Chloroform-fumigation-extraction method (CFE), according to Vance et al. (1987), was used to determine microbial biomass carbon (Cmic) and nitrogen (Nmic). C and N were extracted from each fumigated and non-fumigated replicate (10 g) with 40 ml 0.5 M K2SO4. The suspension was horizontally shaken (30 Min, 150 rpm) and centrifuged (30 Min, 4400 x g). Fumigated sample replicates were incubated with CHCl3 for 24 hours. C and N concentrations in dissolved (1:4, extract:deion. H2O) extracts were measured with a TOC/TN analyzer (Multi N/C 2100S, Analytik Jena AG, Jena, Germany). The kEC factor (Joergensen, 1996) and the kEN factor of Brookes et al. (1985) were used to calculate microbial C and N, respectively. Based on the non-fumigated samples extractable organic carbon (EOC) and extractable nitrogen (EN) were determined.
Microbial community composition, in terms of bacterial and fungal biomass, was measured from soil phospholipid fatty acid (PLFA) composition. Extraction was conducted according to Frostegard et al. (1991), and alkaline methanolysis was performed after Dowling et al. (1986), to gain fatty acid methyl esters (FAME). Each FAME was classified as bacterial or fungal according to Ruess and Chamberlain (2010): PLFA FAMEs a15:0, i15:0, i16:0, and i17:0 represent gram positive bacteria, cy17:0 and cy19:0 represent gram negative bacteria and the sum of gram positive and gram negative bacteria together with PLFA FAME 16:1ω7 were used to represent total soil bacteria, while PLFA FAME 18:2ω6,9 served as a fungal indicator.
Bacterial cell numbers were determined using a protocol modified after Lunau et al. (2005) and counted by epifluorescence microscopy under blue excitation (Zeiss Axio Imager M2, filter set 38 HE eGFP; Göttingen, Germany) at a magnification of 1,000x. A minimum of 20 microscopic fields were counted for each sample.
Potential nitrification assay (PNA) was performed according to the procedures described in Hoffmann et al. (2007). For determination of potential nitrification rates, 10 ml of ammonium sulfate solution (10 mM) were added as substrate to 2.5 g fresh weight of soil.
Denitrifying enzyme activity (DEA) was determined using a modified assay of Smith and Tiedje (1979), without the addition of chloramphenicol, as preliminary assays showed that no de novo synthesis of denitrifying enzyme occurred within a 2 h incubation period. In brief, 2 g field-moist soil was incubated in air-tight bottles (inner volume 118 ml) with 5 ml solution containing 1.1 mM KNO3 and 1 mM glucose.
DNA was extracted from duplicate homogenized soil subsamples (300 mg each) using the FastDNA® SPIN Kit for Soil (MP Biomedicals, Solon, OH, USA) following the manufacturer's protocol. Concentrations of DNA extracted from both sample replicates were measured independently on a NanoDrop® ND-1000 spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific, Wilmington, DE, USA), then pooled and re-measured to confirm the final DNA concentration of each sample. Samples for quantitative real time PCR (qPCR) measurement were diluted with ultra-pure water to a target concentration of 5 ng DNA µl-1. The following microbial groups were measured by qPCR: abundance of bacterial16S rRNA as proxy for the total bacterial community; abundance of archaeal 16S rRNA to assess the total archaeal community; nifH gene to assess the nitrogen fixing community; genes encoding the catalytic subunits ammonia monooxygenase enzymes of archaea (amoA AOA) and bacteria (amoA AOB) to evaluate the ammonia-oxidizing community (Stempfhuber et al., 2016); and nirS-, nirK- and nosZ-type denitrifier genes, which encode cytochrome cd1 heme nitrite reductase, copper-nitrite-reductase, and nitrous oxide reductase, respectively, for the denitrifying community. Amplification of the qPCR products for nitrogen fixers and ammonia-oxidizers was conducted on a 7300 Real-Time PCR System, (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA, USA).

bgc:variable.bgc:name: SoilMois
bgc:variable.bgc:description: soil water content in percent of soil dry matter

bgc:variable.bgc:name: VolSoilMois
bgc:variable.bgc:description: volumetric soil moisture calculated from BD core

bgc:variable.bgc:name: Stones
bgc:variable.bgc:description: weight of stones from BD core (g per core)

bgc:variable.bgc:name: Roots
bgc:variable.bgc:description: weight of dried roots from BD core (g per core)

bgc:variable.bgc:name: Nmin
bgc:variable.bgc:description: sum of ammonium and nitrate content

bgc:variable.bgc:name: GramPosBac
bgc:variable.bgc:description: PLFA-FAMEs for gram positive bacteria in soil

bgc:variable.bgc:name: GramNegBac
bgc:variable.bgc:description: PLFA-FAMEs for gram negative bacteria in soil

bgc:variable.bgc:name: BacTot
bgc:variable.bgc:description: PLFA-FAMEs for total bacteria, incl. GramPosBac and GramNegBac in soil

bgc:variable.bgc:name: ProtozoaTot
bgc:variable.bgc:description: PLFA-FAMEs for soil invertebrates (e.g. Protozoa, Nematodes, Collembola, Lumbricidae) in soil

bgc:variable.bgc:name: AOA
bgc:variable.bgc:description: soil gene abundances, ammonia oxidizing archaea

bgc:variable.bgc:name: AOB
bgc:variable.bgc:description: soil gene abundances, ammonia oxidizing bacteria

bgc:variable.bgc:name: PotenNitrif
bgc:variable.bgc:units: ng NO2-N g-1 soil DM h-1

bgc:variable.bgc:name: DEA
bgc:variable.bgc:units: µg N2O-N g-1 soil DM h-1

bgc:variable.bgc:name: DEAnoC2H2
bgc:variable.bgc:units: µg N2O-N g-1 soil DM dw h-1
bgc:variable.bgc:description: denitrification enzyme activity of soil without nosZ inhibition

bgc:variable.bgc:name: DEACalcDiffs
bgc:variable.bgc:units: µg N2-N g-1 soil DM h-1
bgc:variable.bgc:description: difference between DEA and DEAnoC2H2 yields N2 production

bgc:variable.bgc:name: planttot
bgc:variable.bgc:description: biomass of total living plant cover

bgc:variable.bgc:name: abovetot
bgc:variable.bgc:description: biomass of planttot plus litter biomass
